messages.message:
Two UW–Madison student groups have been suspended on an interim basis while the university investigates allegations of sidewalk chalkings by the groups that endorsed violence, supported terrorist organizations and were antisemitic, the university announced Monday.
Mecha de UW Madison and Anticolonial Scientists were suspended after UW’s Committee on Student Organizations received complaints and media reports Sunday and Monday about the chalking event at the Dane County Farmers’ Market in Downtown Madison on Saturday.
The suspension also bars them from using university-owned office space, hosting or co-hosting events, travel and reserving university facilities.
Other chalkings said “Power to Hezbollah,” “Down with ‘Israel’ down with ‘USA’” and “All cops are Zionists,” the newspaper reported.
“Our only goal and the only goal of the event is to support Palestine and Palestinian liberation,” he said.

Two UW–Madison student groups have been suspended on an interim basis while the university investigates allegations of sidewalk chalkings by the groups that endorsed violence, supported terrorist organizations and were antisemitic, the university announced Monday.
Mecha de UW Madison and Anticolonial Scientists were suspended after UW's Committee on Student Organizations received complaints and media reports Sunday and Monday about the chalking event at the Dane County Farmers' Market in Downtown Madison on Saturday.
The suspension also bars them from using university-owned office space, hosting or co-hosting events, travel and reserving university facilities.
Other chalkings said “Power to Hezbollah,” “Down with ‘Israel’ down with ‘USA’” and “All cops are Zionists," the newspaper reported.
Mecha de UW Madison did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment and the person who answered the group's phone number said she was no longer part of the group.

Students at schools including Yale University, New York University, Harvard University, University of Texas at Austin, University of Southern California and more have launched protests.

Biden said “There’s no place on any campus in America” or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.
He added, “We’re not a lawless country — we are a civil society”In conjunction with Biden’s speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond.
And the State Department’s special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.
Trump’s campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel’s Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates’ responses on antisemitism.

President Joe Biden arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., from a weekend trip to his Delaware home, Monday, May 6, 2024.

Biden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack — the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust — with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.

Biden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas “brought to life” that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.

Washington CNN —President Joe Biden on Tuesday issued a call to fight a swiftly rising tide of antisemitism, saying such hate has no place in America as he connected the horrors of the Holocaust to Hamas’ attack on Israel.
Biden’s speech was a somber moment of reflection amid a tense and pivotal time in his reelection push.
“This ancient hatred of Jews didn’t begin with the Holocaust – it didn’t end with the Holocaust, either, or even after our victory in World War II.
And on Monday, a day ahead of Biden’s speech, second gentleman Doug Emhoff hosted a number of Jewish students at the White House for a roundtable.
Biden’s speech came one day after Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day.

Washington (CNN) — President Joe Biden on Tuesday issued a call to fight a swiftly rising tide of antisemitism, saying such hate has no place in America as he connected the horrors of the Holocaust to Hamas’ attack on Israel.
Biden’s speech was a somber moment of reflection amid a tense and pivotal time in his reelection push.
“This ancient hatred of Jews didn’t begin with the Holocaust – it didn’t end with the Holocaust, either, or even after our victory in World War II.
And on Monday, a day ahead of Biden’s speech, second gentleman Doug Emhoff hosted a number of Jewish students at the White House for a roundtable.
Biden’s speech came one day after Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day.

Washington CNN —President Joe Biden on Tuesday issued a call to fight a “ferocious surge” of antisemitism, saying such hate has no place in America as he connected the horrors of the Holocaust to Hamas’ attack on Israel.
Biden’s speech was a somber – yet impassioned – moment of reflection amid a tense and pivotal time in his reelection push.
He cited specific reports from Jewish students of being physically assaulted or harassed while walking on campus, antisemitic statements, including that Jewish students should “go back to Poland,” verbal abuse and swastikas found on dorm room doors.
On Monday, a day ahead of Biden’s speech, second gentleman Doug Emhoff hosted a number of Jewish students at the White House for a roundtable.
Biden’s speech came one day after Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day.

He cited specific reports from Jewish students of being physically assaulted or harassed while walking on campus, antisemitic statements, including that Jewish students should “go back to Poland,” verbal abuse and swastikas found on dorm room doors.
On Monday, a day ahead of Biden’s speech, second gentleman Doug Emhoff hosted a number of Jewish students at the White House for a roundtable.
Biden’s speech came one day after Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day.
